Post Text: Community saves.After being a top seller in my 20s, I was fired or laid off 3 times in my mid-30s. I found myself directionless in a period when I was supposed to have ‘figured it out’.I lacked confidence in what was next or if I’d ever be successful.And this ate at me. My friends were all doing bigger things and I was going around in circles.After losing my job at the beginning of Covid, I decided to lean into LinkedIn and build a DM chat of others leaning in too.Essentially a small ‘community’ of folks in sales and marketing in SaaS . My goal was to leverage this group to find a new job in Sales leadership.The energy of the the group was palpable; we all fed off each other and because we kept breaking LinkedIn chat, moved to Slack. We added in RevOps & Customer Success pros to the mix to make it a complete 'go-to-market' community.Two recruiters saw the insane growth and told me to stop interviewing for jobs to build this thing out.Building Community was going to be my new job. BUT I NEEDED MONEY NOW! And, we weren't making it (yet).I took a bet that this community, now named ‘RevGenius’ was my calling and went all in.I grew RevGenius to 40k GTM Professionals within 3 years and I hired myself along the way as revenue grew.We did 7 figures in revenue last year.I’m no longer directionless.Community saved me.This is my story.What's yours?🌊

Post Text: My mom passed away 6 years ago today; this is our last dinner together.I wrote her a text this morning (I obviously can’t send):I love you so much mom. I'm not sure I told you the full extent and hope you realize it.I wish I could just respond to this text and you'd get it. That I'd see you later. That all would be alright. I wish with all my heart I'd have 1 more day with you. Even if I didn't get more than a couple mins alone with you. I know you'd want to dedicate all your time to your grand daughters. But I also know you'd want to make sure your children were ok, and that they would be ok without you.We are ok and it's because the lessons you taught us. But it doesn't mean we miss you any less. I live every day now trying my best. To be the best person I can be. I stumble at times, but I'm getting much better. I know you'd be proud. You asked me if I was happy the night before you passed. That's all you really wanted for us. I said I was, but I didn't really know. I had a dying mother and job offer that wouldn't pan out. But I've learned happiness is much more than material things and everything going your way, from you. And I'm prioritizing peeling my layers of doubt, anger, and grief away to realize how happy I am. Im a work in progress (let's be real: we all are). Writing this message to you started out as really sad, but now is becoming therapeutic. I feel your love all around me. I hope you're OK, and waiting until we meet again. I know you have your crazy family to keep you company. 😄I know my presence and yours are one, even though you may not be on this earth. In closing:I'm going to be the best uncle I can be, the best partner to Mallory and most importantly love myself. Make sure I'm prioritizing me. Peel back the layers. And love myself so that the love I give others is even more powerful. I love you with all my heart, my sweet and beautiful mom. Until we meet again, your favorite son,JaredMy mother Risë Beth Cowen-Robin was 62 years young when she passed away of Cancer today in 2018.The same disease that took her brother before 50 years old and her mother around the same age. Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: People didn't expect this to happen. Not to her.This was the last thing anyone would've thought from:- A girl from a small town in Ohio to a blue-collar family.- Who went to a state school in Ohio.- Who had to nanny for a NJ family to get to NYC.- Who had to take underpaid mediocre internships in the city to get started.- Who entered a male-dominated space where women had it hard.- Who had to sleep on a couch with a dead cat in the freezer.- Who climbed the ranks without any nepotism or help.- Who earned her first chance at Creative Director at Airbnb.- Who lost that chance when Airbnb mag shut down.- Who bounced back to land the top Creative gig at Cosmo a year later.- Who happened to be up for 4 medals at the most prestigious magazine award ceremony...People didn't think she would win.So when I got the first text yesterday that Mallory (my partner) did the undoable, I cried.She said she landed a medal. I ran home in excitement.She was too nervous to celebrate with me (her team was on a zoom) and kicked me out.I waited in the hallway, listening in eagerly.I heard another (positive) shriek of excitement. I texted her asking if that was her second!?She said it was. Before the day was done she had won 3 medals (1 gold, and 2 silver) against the BEST OF THE BEST in magazines. Nobody expected this, not from her.But, that's not who she is. She's an inspiration to little girls in rural towns without a silver spoon or Ivy League education, and just a dream.She's also my hero. And yesterday, she made me believe anything is truly possible.❤️

Post Text: Yesterday I asked about which version of Jared you'd hire. Today, I'm going to tell you about the growth I experienced at each stage:Stage 1: First big job. I was an AE at FedEx looking for validation that I was actually good at sales. I was passed over for a promotion 4 times before I secured it. It was because my numbers were the 4th best - super objective. And I realized it was something I could control. So I did.That promotion led me to my dream Field Sales job (where I had to wear a suit every day - see pic 1) and eventually to President's Club. I had a chip on my shoulder from being passed over and vowed to reward the manager and team that took a chance on me. My 'Victor' story helped develop confidence (and cockiness) in my abilities. I decided that the ceiling in logistic sales was too low for my ambition and decided technology was the way.Stage 2: I landed a job transitioning into tech at a company called Granify. I was able to make a lateral move to an AE; but had to take over a $20k base salary pay cut. From $85k base to $60k base to get in. It was a seed startup without any paying customers. Nor product that worked. I'd make up the gap in my fat commission checks I told myself. I believed in the vision fully. And I had a little bit of equity. I was ready to hit it big. This pic (#2) shows me bright-eyed and bushy-tailed on a trip to Edmonton, the company's HQ. I'm wearing a shirt I got from Barney's Warehouse Sale (RIP) and now am opening up my personality at work. My style is improving.What this pic doesn't show you: I didn't make the fat commission checks. It took a while for the product to work (and we did go to Series A profitably). When the product didn't work I decided to build a side project - a fashion mag with my best friend Carlos. That was the tipping point to my style improving even more. As satisfying as it was to be figuring out my path, I imploded. I was barely paying rent on my meager base salary (in NYC). My numbers were nonexistent and landing any lateral job would be just as hard as landing this one was.I couldn't sleep through the night at one point for like a week straight. I went to meditation to survive. It was really bad.And then the product started to improve. I made a commission check or two (never hit $100k in a year though). My side project won Best International Fashion Film and my side hustle was flourishing: 10k monthly site visitors (it was enough to create a small movement, but not enough to make serious money).At this point, I started actually dressing more like pic 3, at least outside of work (I worked from home so was comfy all day).Stage 3:This pic was taken at an art exhibit by my CEO at the time.I was running growth at an art blockchain marketplace a few years ago.I was able to fully transition from who I was 'on the side' to my day job. And found a job and space (the art world!) that valued that. The most interesting 'Jared' to me is (see below)...

Post Text: I once interviewed for a job selling knives.I was young and asked a silly question to the trainer:Why aren’t you on any leaderboards?The office was plastered with leaderboards and this person onboarding us wasn’t on any. Post Text: A vast majority of resumes folks send me won't land interviews.Sellers, here's a format to help you level up your resumes:After you list Job Title, Company, Dates-Line 1: Tell exactly what you did, what you soldLine 2: Tell the titles of who you called on, and how you got meetingsLine 3: How did you do against your peers; how'd you do against $ goalLine 4: Who were the logos you closed/recognizable clientsHere's an example of how that looks on my old resume:● Sold international and domestic shipping services and associated SaaS shipping management systems to a wide range of mid-large corporations throughout the NYC area.● Called on COO, CEO, Supply Chain/Operations VP and director levels; all contacts are results of cold outreach, previous contacts, and renewals.● Consistently ranked in the top 10 percent of salespeople worldwide against a $20 million annual goal regularly at 110%+ of quota.● Clients included Gilt Groupe, Joe Fresh, Karla Otto, Inked and Nylon Magazines, Little Miss Matched, Assouline Publishing,Bravado International Group, Nest Fragrances, Strivectin, Bodum, John Hardy Jewelry, and Skip Hop.● Promoted 4 times in 6 year period based on surpassing 100% of goal annually every year.The lines after the first 4?Don't matter as much.You'll notice I added how many times I was promoted in 6 years.It's cute and positive, but the meat is in the first 4.Let's tag folks hiring (link JD) and folks looking.Let's put more people in great jobs!I hope this helps.🌊

Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: The most jacked gym trainer with the most personal accolades isn't always the best for you. Here's my story of 2 trainers:Professional bodybuilder trainer:- Had no time to understand my needs outside our sessions- Tried to upsell me on more sessions to get results- Wouldn't help me create plans away from him- Didn't ask me to track my improvements- Worked me out extremely hard- Won bodybuilding contests- $120 / session, 5 for $600- No substantial resultsVirtual personal trainer:- Understood me: collaborated on goals in our first conversation- Said I may only need to buy 1 month virtually if I absorb all- Created a daily training plan and food plan for my goals- Hopped on 1 hr zooms back-to-back days to plan w/me- Texts me daily asking about improvements toward goal- Has me video myself in gym and critiques form IRT- Tells me to text food labels at grocery store- Is my biggest supporter and advocate- Results - lost 3 lbs in 3 days - $150/month 2 personal trainer friends each won my business. But only 1 is keeping it. The idea of understanding goals and aligning is CRITICAL. This may not be SaaS gtm, but there are far too many similarities to sales and cs to not share. Have any stories to share?Also, on my way to the gym - what do you think about my gym fit?Happy Sunday!

Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: I got to sit down with Morgan J Ingram  and break down his B2B Influencer Marketing Playbook:Morgan is the founder and CEO of Amp. They enable B2B organizations to leverage B2B influencers, subject matter experts to produce pipeline generating content. There's three tiers to influencer marketing that he’s now identified and distinguished.Brand ambassador:This is someone who typically would act as, like, an affiliate. So, like, you may have someone who's starting out, but they just don't have a bigger follower count, but they have a really niche and engaged audience. Test it out and use, like, affiliates and things of that nature, affiliate links, et cetera.The Influencer:What everyone's doing right now. You pay someone x amount for them to post about your brands, and then you may have some other things that you do with them, some videos, some activations, cool things that we've seen on LinkedIn.The SME (Subject Matter Expert):Morgan believes this is the true north star of B2B influencer marketing. People who have expertise are credible in their field and in their craft, so they're able to develop and create credible content that people actually want to consume and the buyers want to hear from, which leads to you getting more pipeline.  They are able to integrate into the companies day to day GTM motion.Companies he thinks are doing content well (follow them): Cognism , Kaspr , Champify , HockeyStack , AudiencePlus He breaks this down fully in this week’s collab ->  https://lnkd.in/evPXrPGK🐝

Dale, a fractional Chief GTM Officer, walks us through aligning the org to combat churn and scale effectively:Marketing:- Align the Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) with the value proposition.- Validate the alignment through customer feedback.- Monitor and update the ICP and value proposition regularly.Sales:- Ensure that the sales team qualifies prospects effectively.-Align the features and functionality sold with what is actually available.- Measure customer satisfaction and feedback regarding the sales process.Marketing to Sales:- Integrate marketing into the sales process.- Listen to customer conversations and gain insights.- Establish a well-organized system for capturing and sharing customer information.Deal Desk and Customer Success:- Include a deal desk to ensure alignment on pursuing specific deals.- Involve customer success managers (CSMs) near the end in the sales process.Communicate the customer’s needs and challenges effectively.Product and Customer Success:- Monitor how customers are utilizing the product.- Address low product usage and uncover underlying problems.- Use metrics and indicators to assess customer satisfaction and value.Leadership:- Prioritize customer needs, value and satisfaction over profit.-Balance revenue and profit goals with customer value and fit.- Promote a customer-centric culture within the organization.By aligning these five pillars and adopting a customer-centric mindset, businesses can improve customer retention and build lasting relationships while enhancing their bottom line. Read the full article unpacking this and more.👇🏼

Post Text: If you’re the smartest person in the room, you’re in the wrong room.The excitement I’ve had launching RevRoom mimicked the excitement from RevGenius. It feels like we are solving a major challenge that so many GTM leaders are experiencing.At the turn of the year, many Senior Leaders of the community came to me expressing that they wanted a new, more intimate, and vetted space and weren’t really getting it from anywhere else. Enter RevRoom.We wanted to make sure that RevRoom was an exclusive space. We understood the importance of providing a safe and tailored environment specifically for senior leaders. So curating the RevRoom group exclusively for VPs and C-Suite executives became a critical focus for us.We decided to limit the cohort to 150 members (tops) to safeguard that.  We integrated via Slack Connect to reduce noise and to allow access to the community from members’ company Slacks.  As a result, there are not dozens of channels but just one or two core ones.Finally, we’ve decided to roll out five pillars to provide members qith a more unique and structured experience. Five Pillars of RevRoomCore GroupsThese groups of 8 meet monthly to discuss their biggest challenges in a private setting.  Virtual CommunityOur Slack is unique because of the 150 people/ channel (‘room’) and weekly roundtable discussions in an intimate setting. Our promise? We’ll keep cohorts at 150. Live GatheringsThe in-person community where we’re rolling out dinners and retreats. Expert-Led Insight SessionsLearning series, where we will feature some of the world’s best speakers and subject matter experts, talking about the topics our members ask for.Member BenefitsWe are introducing B2C-like perks and experiences (think hotel discounts, etc.) to meet our members’ lifestyle needs.Collaborating on the Future of B2B GTMThe goal is to create a unique and intimate, community-led experience from the go.We want to grow thoughtfully. We want to grow together and deliver on our promise to make RevRoom the trusted space for revenue leaders.Here are a few of the go-to-market VPs and C-level executives that make up our community today:Christina Brady 🐙  (SVP Sales, Spekit), Sid Kumar  (SVP RevOps, Hubspot), Jenn Steele  (CEO, Kissmetrics), Adam Jay 📈  (CRO), Gemma Cipriani-Espineira  (Founder, CS Angels), Mary Poppen  (CCO, involve.ai), Paul Rosen  (CRO, ShipBob), Mollie Bodensteiner (Head of Global RevOps, Deel), Mark Kilens  (CMO, Airmeet), Shannon (Sweeny) Curran  (VP Marketing, MadKudu), Scott Sutton  (CBO, ZoomInfo) and many others from Series A high-growth startups to public companies.  They’re talking about big, audacious GTM challenges, along with personal ones.The leaders in RevRoom are some of the most forward-thinking executives in the space and they’re reimagining the future of GTM. If you’re a senior GTM leader looking for a space to lean into and learn from, we are here for you.🙏🏼

Post Text: How does HockeyStack generate more revenue from their content than your brand does?Because of Hockeystack Labs insane only KPI (you’re going to want to read this)…Canberk Beker their head of growth set an internal KPI-We will come to this point where we won't be asking people to share reports, we won't give to influencers to share the reports, but they will do it organically. And after the fourth, maybe fifth report, it started happening. Here’s HockeyStack Labs Growth Loop:1. HockeyStack Labs came out with a data report they thought was interesting and people liked it. 2. They told HockeyStack what else they wanted to hear, because they were getting a lot of value from it (and they weren’t getting it from anywhere else). They needed more to help them make smart business decisions.3. HockeyStack encouraged them to start requesting topics they wanted data on and that they thought they could get even more value from.4. HockeyStack listened to them and created reports based on a combo of most requested + what they thought would be most interesting internally.5. Their audience got even more value and shared it on social media with their followers and gave feedback for the next reports.  The loop just keeps going. Results:They are generating like 50% of our pipeline from this organically.We are actually talking about millions. And the interesting thing is that the pipeline comes from organic traffic. The website traffic has also increased by a lot.Read the full playbook: https://lnkd.in/epkDakYiSo they’re giving people what they actually need and want vs just sharing their POV and making their content one-sided.And the people are loving it.Imagine that.🔁

Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: Hot take: A large % of 'Strategic Advisors' are just Brand Ambassadors with a more important sounding title. But, why?Sat down with Morgan J Ingram for the Collab's Saturday issue. The Brand Ambassador is the first of 3 tiers in Morgan's B2B Influencer playbook.He's starting to not like the term Strategic Advisor because a lot of people position Strategic Advisors as what we're calling a brand ambassador. He thinks a lot of people label people as strategic advisors to get pushed by the algorithm when you post the announcement. It does that.So he understand why people do that. Fair play. At the same time, that person really probably isn't actually doing any strategic advising. They're just posting. It's really just an ambassador. But no one likes that word [ambassador] in B2B.A lot of creators don't want to be called 'brand ambassadors'. But the thing is, that is effectively what you are at this moment. You are a brand ambassador for this brand. You're an affiliate right now. You have an affiliate link. You may be getting paid, you know, a thousand, $2,000 a month, which is great. But that's the realm you're playing in, is the brand ambassador. So how you monitor that is you typically are probably going to get five to eight brand ambassadors:- And you're just seeing are you getting more uptick in your traffic on your website? - Are you getting more uptick in your LinkedIn followers as people start to talk about you a little bit more.That's how you're going to gauge success. - And then obviously the affiliate is how people are clicking the affiliate link that converts to actual opportunities. So these are things that he thinks about the brand ambassador level.I personally refuse to take advisor roles where equity and/or up front pay is not included, nor tied to requirements for me to post on social.I agree with Morgan and think it 'cheapens' what advising a company means.Still, there's an important place for Ambassadors in driving demand.Read Morgan's full playbook -> https://lnkd.in/evPXrPGKShould we change the name of 'strategic advisors' to 'brand ambassadors' and align more with their goals?What do you think?

Post Text: As I go through unread messages in my LinkedIn inbox this AM…I have a hot take:If you’re asking somebody you’ve never met before for their time (especially if you’re not selling them anything), you are indeed selling them.Hopping on a Zoom call or meeting up IRL costs time. Make sure there’s value for them in spending that time that goes beyond “talking sales strategies” or “getting to know my network”.Nobody really wants to turn down or not respond to a human to human connection. Post Text: Before Michael Jordan, a person was not a brand. Brands were companies.Michael Jordan changed that.Collaborative Growth is how companies and individuals partner to grow both brands.Michael Jordan was the OG that started this.  The Collab is bringing it to B2B.Here’s your 5-step collaboration strategy:1. Be clear on what you want to achieve (Goals and KPIs clearly set).In Nike’s case, they created a forecast of $3M in 4 years and blew past that hitting $126M year 1.2. Be OK to pay! Money and/or equity are both acceptable. Michael Jordan received both $2.5 million over 5 years and 10% of the sales. It was a mutually beneficial structure that both greatly benefited from.3. Be ready to collaborate.Collaborate = partner for more than 1 or 2 activities. It’s building trust over time.4. Be OK to start imperfectly.This is a marathon, not a sprint. Embrace the roadblocks. Nike designed the first Air Jordans in the distinctive colors of red, black, and white. Despite facing fines of $5,000 for each game Jordan wore the non-compliant shoes, Nike embraced the controversy, covering the fines and allowing the shoes to stand out.5. Be OK with handing over the spotlight to the collaborator.Nike -> Air Jordans -> Jordan Brand.Jordan set the stage for collaborative growth. The revolution is only starting…Read the full article “Michael Jordan, the Original Collaborator”: https://lnkd.in/eV-vPUdi

Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: It may only be June, but planning for 2024 is already underway.  David Maxey, MBA writes about Next-Level Sales and Pre-Sales Annual Planning: Two ApproachesBottoms-up forecasting, starting with people and ending with a Top line revenue target; or Top-down, starting with a revenue target and fitting people into this target.For pre-sales and sales, the main focus is ensuring you have enough Account Executives to cover the revenue targets and that those Account Executives have enough SDR and/or Solution Engineering support to cover the pipeline needs for the revenue targets.  A secondary focus that tends to get less attention is marketing.  Specifically, is marketing bringing in enough leads to support the sales targets? Usually, your marketing and sales leaders work together to decide what portion of the pipeline will be covered by marketing vs. pure sales outreach.When you look at these two focus areas, it would appear that from a planning standpoint, you only have a little to be able to move around besides the hiring dates of the people needed to execute. And that’s mostly true, but there are 4 other main levers that pre-sales and sales has a lot of control over. - Ramp Time- Average Selling Price- Sales Cycle- Conversion RatesRead the full article and check out David walking you through a video of setting up a plan for success.It’s one you won’t want to miss.👇🏼

Post Text: Alignment may be the most important growth lever your company isn’t getting right. Jim Soss shared a great framework in support of Sales & Marketing alignment.The framework encompasses six primary activities that foster open communication, align goals and metrics, and promote a culture of collaboration:1. Leadership Alignment: Setting a unified tone and demonstrating visible synergy among leaders.2. Integrated GTM Strategy: Creating a unified strategy and coordinating efforts for a cohesive and effective attack.3. Performance Connection: Establishing joint metrics that span the entire buyer journey.4.  Integrated Goals: Collaborating on joint planning and budgeting processes.5. Team Building: Defining clear expectations and fostering regular communication within the teams.6. Joint Storytelling: Coordinating go-to-market presentations and packaging to convey a cohesive message.Read full article in comments where he unpacks each activity in detail.👇🏼

Author: Jared Robin
Post Text: The 4 most important skills as a startup founder or any early stage company employee:1. Understand intimately what you don't know (but need to). This awareness of your gaps in getting your product or service to the next milestones will allow you to figure out either how to level up yourself or (more importantly) -2. Have a network of people that you have loads of confidence in that can help you directly fill your most important gaps or you trust can introduce you to somebody you can bring in to. For me, this is why I brought in  Jason Hubbard (I had a personal gap with operations and leadership - Mallory Lee, Mollie Bodensteiner and others are also great folks to help). Join communities like RevGenius to help here.3. Build your 'figure it out' ability. This is a combination of grit, curiosity, hustle, and more. Things will go wrong - I can guarantee that. There will come a time when you don't have answers to important questions and quick answers in general aren't easily found. Can you stick with things, test things, iterate, and 'figure it out'. When you run out of runway, are you able to keep the company afloat? Can you put in systems to not get too close to the edge again, etc... which leads me to - 4. Ability to remain even keeled.This doesn't get spoken about enough. The mental side of being a founder (or early stage employee who probably has taken a pay cut) has the ability to trigger every single emotion you have (and new ones you didn't realize were inside you). Can you remain even keeled and non reactive. For me, I go through waves. Sometimes it's harder than others; I'll lean on #3 to figure out my mental state.Right now I'm going through therapy and about to start daily meditation again. In addition to a heightened focus on my physical well being.What are some skills you've developed that have helped you greatly?
